list.title: Question 1
list.content:
The diagram below shows a tennis ball of massmmmstriking a wall with an initial velocity,uuu, and rebounding with velocityvvv. A second, softer ball of the same mass strikes the wall with the same speed but rebounds with a slower rebound speed.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4bbeffe1-fadb-4f69-a8f6-5a1deb1f20d3/images/a440cac5-43c9-4b14-97ec-4b768f633978/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.33.06%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Which of the following statements is correct about the magnitudes of the impulse and change in momentum applied to the second ball compared to the first?\hspace{1em}Impulse\hspace{1em}Change in momentum\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}GreaterSmaller\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}SmallerGreater\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}GreaterGreater\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}SmallerSmaller
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The change in momentum and impulse applied to the ball are equal, because the impulse is defined as the change in momentum. Increasing one is the same as increasing the other and vice-versa. The slower rebound speed of the second ball causes a decrease in the magnitude of the impulse since the change in momentum is smaller if the final speedvvvis smaller.J=Δp=m(v−−u)=m(v+u)J = \Delta p = m(v - -u) = m(v + u)J=Δp=m(v−−u)=m(v+u)

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
An object of massMMMon a string moves in a circle of radiusrrrat a constant speed.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6590a45d-55a7-400f-b7b5-4f31b825e7ad/images/ab24556d-04d2-418a-b7f4-9e1ca037a3f1/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.28.54%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Below are three statements about the motion of the object:I.\hspace{1.1em}The resultant work done on the object is zero.II.\hspace{0.8em}The velocity of the object is constant.III.\hspace{0.5em}The object is acceleratingWhich of the statements is/are true?A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I and III only
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:I is correct.The accelerating force is always perpendicular to the direction of motion, therefore no work is done.W=Fscos⁡θW = Fs \cos\thetaW=Fscosθ, andθ\thetaθis always 90°\degree°, andcos⁡90°=0\cos 90 \degree =0cos90°=0Also,W=ΔEkW=\Delta E_kW=ΔEk​and the speed of the object is constant so there is no change in kinetic energy.II is incorrect.Because velocity is a vector quantity and the direction is constantly changing, velocity is not constant.III is correct.Because velocity is constantly changing, the object is always accelerating.

list.title: Question 5
list.content: A car of massmmmand a truck of mass3m3m3mtravelling in opposite directions collide and stick together. The speeds of the car and the truck just before the crash are2v2v2vandvvvrespectively. What is their speed after the collision?A.14v\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{1}{4}v41​vB.45v\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{4}{5}v54​vC.54v\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{5}{4}v45​vD.4v\hspace{1em}  	4v4v
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The vehicles move in opposite directions, therefore the total momentum before the collision ism(2v)+(−3m)v=−mvm(2v)+(-3m)v=-mvm(2v)+(−3m)v=−mvBy the principle of conservation of momentum, the momentum of the vehicles after the collision is equal to the total momentum before the collision.−mv=(m+3m)vf-mv=\left(m+3m\right)v_f−mv=(m+3m)vf​wherevfv_fvf​is the velocity of the vehicles after the collisions.vf=−mv4mv_f=\dfrac{-mv}{4m}vf​=4m−mv​vf=−v4v_f=\dfrac{-v}{4}vf​=4−v​Therefore the speed is14v\dfrac{1}{4}v41​v.

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
The diagram below shows an object attached to a light inextensible string. The object is travelling in a horizontal circle at a constant speed.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e1407380-c5d8-4cf6-8000-1ed0057396fd/images/86154aae-6a39-4d62-927f-7719e616b6c7/image.png)

What is the direction of the resultant force acting on the object? Select from the labeled arrows on the diagram.
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The object is moving in a circle at a constant speed so the resultant force = centripetal force. The centripetal force is directed towards the center of the circular path that the object is following. The answer is D.There are two forces acting on the object. Weight (acting in the direction C) and tension (acting in direction A). The resultant of these two forces in the vertical plane is zero. The resultant force is the horizontal component of the tension (acting in the direction D).

list.title: Question 9
list.content: As a truck is brought to rest, the brakes apply a force of5.1×1035.1 \times 10^35.1×103N. Which answer best describes the magnitude of the change in momentum of the truck if the brakes are applied for 3.0 s?A.\hspace{1em}151515kN sB.\hspace{1em}150001500015000N sC.\hspace{1em}15.315.315.3kN sD.\hspace{1em}153001530015300N s
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:NOTEthis question requires students to use their judgement to determine the best answer, using standard scientific conventions.Impulse = change in momentum =FtF \,tFtSo the magnitude of the change in momentum:Δp=(5.1×103\Delta p= (5.1 \times 10^3Δp=(5.1×103)(3.0) = 15300 N sAll responses match this quantity but the number of significant figures needs to be considered. As both of the values used in the calculation have two significant figures, there should be two significant figures in the answer.In the answer150001500015000N s, the number of significant figures is unclear. It could be 2, 3, 4 or 5. The response151515kN s clearly has two significant figures, so it is the best answer.

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
A football player bounced the ball off their head as shown while diving sideways:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/db6d3d8f-a4f9-44a6-ac1d-3d502dc3fe03/images/625404da-8e05-4718-839c-665afe99d9b7/PH0146-1.png)

Which of the following gives a Newton's Third Law pair of forces that applies to this situation?Force 1Force 2\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}Force of the ball on the playerForce of the ball on the earth\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}Force of the player on the earthForce of the ball on the player\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}Force of the earth on the ballForce of the ball on the earth\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}Force of the earth on the playerForce of the player on the ball
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The only combination of answers which mentions the correct Newton’s Third Law  force pair is C. In Newton’s Third Law force pairs always occur between only the same two objects.In this case, because the ball and Earth are not in contact, it is the gravitational force that is equal and opposite here.

\hspace{1cm}\hspace{1cm}C.D.

list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Weight always acts vertically downwardsNormal reaction force is always normal (perpendicular) to the surfaceIn order to remain at rest, friction must act up the incline in order to keep the block from sliding down the incline under the action of the component of weight acting down the incline.In diagram B, friction is acting down the incline. This will result in an acceleration down the incline.In diagram C, the normal reaction is acting opposite to the weight whereas normal reaction must always be perpendicular to the contact surface.In diagram D, weight is shown to act at an angle to the vertical, whereas weight always acts vertically downwards.

list.title: Question 13
list.content: A ball of massmmmis falling vertically through the air. The drag force acting on the ball is given bykv2kv^2kv2wherekkkis constant andvvvis the speed of the ball. What is the maximum speed reached by the ball?A.kmg\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{k}{mg}mgk​B.mgk\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{mg}{k}kmg​C.kmg\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{\dfrac{k}{mg}}mgk​​D.mgk\hspace{1em}  \sqrt{\dfrac{mg}{k}}kmg​​
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:While the ball is falling, two opposite forces act on it. These are weight and drag. The speed of the ball increases until the drag force balances the weight. Therefore, the following expression can be written for maximum speedvmaxv_{max}vmax​:k(vmax)2=mgk(v_{max})^2=mgk(vmax​)2=mg(vmax)2=mgk(v_{max})^2=\dfrac{mg}{k}(vmax​)2=kmg​vmax=mgkv_{max}=\sqrt{\dfrac{mg}{k}}vmax​=kmg​​Hence, the correct answer is D.

list.title: Question 15
list.content: Two eggs of equal mass fall from the same height onto a padded floor. One of them is broken while the other one bounces upwards intact. The time of collision is the same for both. Which of the following correctly describes the egg that exerts a greater averge force on the floor and the reason?Egg with greater average forceReason\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}BrokenGreater change in momentum\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}BouncesLess change in momentum\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}BrokenLess change in momentum\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}BouncesGreater change in momentum
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:As the direction of motion of the bouncing egg is changed after the collision, it has a greater change in velocity than the egg that breaks. Therefore, its has a greter change in momentum.The time of collision is the same for both situations. According toF=ΔpΔtF=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}F=ΔtΔp​, the force acting on the egg that bounces back is greater. By using Newton’s third law, it can be stated that the average force acting on the floor from the bouncing egg is greater.

list.title: Question 16
list.content: Small marbles with equal mass but different diameters are released in liquids with different densities. Which of the following combinations of marble and the density of the liquid will result in the shortest time for the marble to fall a given height?  Assume that in all cases the marbles sink in the liquid and the viscosity of the liquid is constant.\hspace{1.5em}Diameter of the marble\hspace{1.5em}\hspace{1.5em}The density of the liquid\hspace{1.5em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}Smaller diameterLower density\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}Greater diameterLower density\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}Smaller diameterHigher density\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}Greater diameterHigher density
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:A released marble can cover the same distance in a shorter time when it has greater acceleration. To get greater acceleration, the resultant force downward should be bigger. Three forces are acting on the ball the weight of the ball, buoyancy, and drag. While buoyancy and drag are upwards, weight is downwards. Note that because the marbles are stated to have equal masses, the downwards force of gravity on both marbles is the same.The buoyant force:Fb=VρgF_b = V\rho gFb​=VρgWeight:W=mgW=mgW=mgDrag:Fd=6πηrvF_d = 6\pi \eta rvFd​=6πηrvThe resultant forceFnetF_{net}Fnet​:Fnet=mg−(Vρg+6πηrv)F_{net}=mg-(V\rho g+6\pi \eta rv)Fnet​=mg−(Vρg+6πηrv)Based on the equation above, when the drag force or buoyancy is reduced, the resultant force becomes greater. As the density of the liquid decreases, the magnitude of the buoyant force decreases.Moreover, a decrease in diameter directly leads to a decrease in drag force and buoyancy.Alternatively, if we consider the terminal velocity, this results when the net force is zero.ThereforeFg=Fd+FbF_g = F_d+F_bFg​=Fd​+Fb​mg=ρVg+6πηrvmg = \rho V g+6\pi \eta rvmg=ρVg+6πηrvSolving for terminal velocity givesv=mg−ρVg6πηrv = \dfrac{mg-\rho V g}{6\pi \eta r}v=6πηrmg−ρVg​Substituting the fomula for the volume of a spherev=mg−ρ(43πr3)g6πηrv = \dfrac{mg-\rho (\frac{4}{3} \pi r^3) g}{6\pi \eta r}v=6πηrmg−ρ(34​πr3)g​We see that asrrrincreases, the numerator will at some point reach zero. This will be the point at which the density of the marble equals the density of the fluid. We are told that the marble always sinks, and so the numerator must remain positive.Looking at the expression, decreasingrrrwill have the effect of both increasing the numerator (thus increasing the velocity) and decreasing the denominator (also increasing the velocity).

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
A jet aircraft is performing a “loop-the-loop” stunt in which it moves in a vertical circular path as shown in the diagram.

list.title: Question 18
list.content:
A stone attached to one end of a rod rotates in a vertical circle at a constant speed. Two positions of the stone at two different instants, X and Y, are shown in the diagram below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d4352f8d-c820-4f4d-bca6-df53ec8d5067/images/791ea751-6d76-46b7-bc0b-d17159b63e87/PH0231-1.png)

In the table below, which row is correct for the centripetal force acting on the stone at X and Y?\hspace{1em}Direction of centripetal force\hspace{1em}\hspace{1em}Magnitude of centripetal force\hspace{1em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}SameSame\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}SameDifferent\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}DifferentSame\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}DifferentDifferent
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The centripetal force on an object undergoing uniform circular motion is always towards the centre of the circle therefore the direction is different at the different locations. The magnitude of centripetal force is dependent on the radius of the circular path and the speed of the object. Since both locations have the same radius and speed, the magnitude of centripetal force is constant throughout the motion. Therefore, the answer is C.

list.title: Question 19
list.content:
The diagram below shows the total upward and downward forces acting on a hot air balloon. The relative magnitudes of the forces are drawn to scale.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/df4cb97a-03e0-4bd8-a84c-8dda7444c026/images/3942c2b5-5966-4703-a368-fe8f703caa1a/PH0968Edit.png)

Below are three independent statements about the possible motion of the balloon.I.The balloon is acceleratingII.The balloon is moving upwardsIII.The balloon is moving downwardsWhich of the statements, when considered independently,couldbe true?A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:I is correct - The diagram shows that the upward force is greater than the downward force. So, there is a net upward force acting on the balloon.F=maF=maF=maso there is an upward acceleration.II could be correct – Balloon could be moving upwards - acceleration is also upwards so speed of the balloon would be increasing.III could be correct – Balloon could be moving downwards - acceleration is upwards so speed of the balloon would be decreasing (deceleration).For linear motion, acceleration tells us nothing about the speed, just how the speed is changing. The balloon could be moving upwards, moving downwards or stationary.

list.title: Question 20
list.content: A car is travelling along a straight line for a total time of 100 s. Throughout this time the driving force provided by the car is 1.2 kN and the total resistive force acting on the car is 500 N.Which row correctly shows the rate of change of momentum and the impulse of the car during the 100 s.Rate of change of momentumImpulse\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}7×102\times 10{^2}×102kg m s−2{^{-2}}−27×100\times 10{^0}×100kg m s−1{^{-1}}−1\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}7×102\times 10{^2}×102kg m s−2{^{-2}}−27×104\times 10{^4}×104kg m s−1{^{-1}}−1\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}1.7×103\times 10{^3}×103kg m s−2{^{-2}}−21.7×101\times 10{^1}×101kg m s−1{^{-1}}−1\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}1.7×103\times 10{^3}×103kg m s−2{^{-2}}−21.7×105\times 10{^5}×105kg m s−1{^{-1}}−1
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Newton's second law states that net force = rate of change of momentum.Therefore, the rate of change of momentum is simply the net force acting on the carΔpΔt=1200\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=1200ΔtΔp​=1200N - 500 N = 700 N = 700 kg m s−2=7×102^{-2}=7 \times 10^2−2=7×102kg m s−2^{-2}−2ImpulseJJJ=FnetΔtF_{net}\Delta tFnet​Δt= (700)(100) = 7×\times×10410{^4}104kg m s−1^{-1}−1

list.title: Question 25
list.content: A rocket ejects hot gas in space in a direction opposite to its travelling direction. What is correct for the magnitude of the momentum and the kinetic energy of the rocket?MomentumKinetic Energy\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}ConservedConserved\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}IncreasedConserved\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}ConservedIncreased\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}IncreasedIncreased
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The rocket is not a closed system. The reaction force from ejecting hot gas will increasingly accelerate the rocket, hence both momentum and kinetic energy will increase.

list.title: Question 26
list.content: A table tennis ball of massmmmis dropped on a level surface from a heightHHH. The ball rebounds to a heighth<Hh < Hh<Hafter impact. Air resistance on the ball is negligible. Which of the following is correct about the nature of the collision and magnitude of the change in momentum (Δp\Delta pΔp) of the ball as a result of this impact?Nature of the collisionChange in momentumΔp\Delta pΔp\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}Elasticm(2gH−2gh)m(\sqrt{2gH}-\sqrt{2gh})m(2gH​−2gh​)\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}Inelasticm(2gH−2gh)m(\sqrt{2gH}-\sqrt{2gh})m(2gH​−2gh​)\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}Elasticm(2gH+2gh)m(\sqrt{2gH}+\sqrt{2gh})m(2gH​+2gh​)\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}Inelasticm(2gH+2gh)m(\sqrt{2gH}+\sqrt{2gh})m(2gH​+2gh​)
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The height of rebound is less than the height of release. This is evidence that some energy is dissipated at the point of impact. Hence inelastic.We can use conservation of energy to find the velocity upon impact:mgH=12mu2mgH=\dfrac{1}{2}mu^2mgH=21​mu2u2=2gHu^2 =2gHu2=2gHu=2gHu=\sqrt{2gH}u=2gH​Similarly, the velocity just after impact is:v=−2ghv=-\sqrt{2gh} \hspace{2em}v=−2gh​Where the negative sign represents the opposite direction touuu(upwards)∴Δp=∣mv−mu∣\therefore \Delta p=|mv-mu|∴Δp=∣mv−mu∣=∣m(v−u)∣=|m(v-u)|=∣m(v−u)∣=m∣(−2gh−2gH)∣=m|(-\sqrt{2gh}-\sqrt{2gH})|=m∣(−2gh​−2gH​)∣Removing the absolute value gives=m(2gH+2gh)=m(\sqrt{2gH}+\sqrt{2gh})=m(2gH​+2gh​)

Define distance.[1]An object moves in a straight line on a level road. The variation of the object's distancedwith timetis shown on the graph below.

list.markScheme:
Length of the path followed✓\checkmark✓Slows down/decelerates✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The slope of the graph gives the speed of the object. The slope decreases betweent=0.5t=0.5t=0.5s andt=1.0t=1.0t=1.0s. Therefore the object slows down.Any evidence for drawing tangent att=0.5st=0.5\, st=0.5s✓\checkmark✓≪28−101−0=≫18±2ms−1\ll\dfrac{28-10}{1-0}=\gg18\pm2\, m\,s^{-1}≪1−028−10​=≫18±2ms−1✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The gradient of the graph at the time of interest gives the instantaneous speed of the object. To find the gradient, the tangent line should be drawn.

The gradient of the tangent line =28−101−0=18\dfrac{28-10}{1-0}=181−028−10​=18m s−1^{-1}−1A straight or a curved line with a negative gradient✓\checkmark✓Starts from the y-intercept and ends up at the x-axis✓\checkmark✓

Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The gradient of the distance-time graph indicates the speed of the object. In one-dimensional motion, speed and velocity have the same magnitude. Since the gradient gets a smaller value with time and ends up with a zero value, velocity gets smaller and be zero at the end.The exact mathematical shape of the distance-time curve is not known, therefore it is not possible to determine the exact shape of the velocity-time graph. A linear graph has been included here, but curvature in the graph is permitted.The final momentum is less than the initial momentum✓\checkmark✓Opposite to the motion/backwards/negative✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The velocity of the object decreases. Therefore, the final momentumpfp_fpf​is less than the initialpip_ipi​momentum. The change in momentumΔp\Delta pΔp;Δp=pf−pi\Delta p=p_f-p_iΔp=pf​−pi​sincepip_ipi​>pfp_fpf​, the result should be negative which indicates the direction of the change in momentum is opposite to the motion of the object.

list.title: Question 29
list.content:
A cargo container is released from an airplane. A parachute is opened remotely a few seconds later to land it safely. Which graph shows the variation of the vertical accelerationaaawith timetttfor the cargo container from when it leaves the plane until landing?A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/45391756-7a52-4e80-90d4-2492905455f9/images/008093a4-5c1e-419d-865d-2fad91185b6a/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%202.15.24%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/45391756-7a52-4e80-90d4-2492905455f9/images/b3a16c1d-d1dc-48dd-832f-9535acc8b644/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%202.15.44%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/45391756-7a52-4e80-90d4-2492905455f9/images/e5911411-0db3-4109-bfcf-712ac30be345/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%202.15.50%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/45391756-7a52-4e80-90d4-2492905455f9/images/3bf1ed62-d84b-4b48-a897-cdec1945761d/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%202.15.56%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The cargo starts with large negative (downward) acceleration. As the cargo container falls, it is speeding up; as it is speeding up, drag force increases, so the acceleration decreases until the cargo container reaches a terminal speed where acceleration is zero. After the parachute is opened, drag force will increase, which is greater than the weight of the cargo container, causing an opposite, upwards, acceleration (deceleration). As the cargo container slows down the drag force decreases, so the net force decreases, and acceleration decreases again until the cargo container reaches a lower terminal speed where acceleration is zero and the forces are balanced.

list.title: Question 30
list.content:
A car enters a roundabout with a speedvvv. The dotted line shows the path of the car. The road is slightly banked inward at an angle to the horizontal.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/46047306-4c31-4e50-8ee4-a0671285fe55/images/8bef058b-da21-4259-8e52-70155256bcbb/PH0298-1.png)

The coefficient of friction between the tires of the car and the road isμ\muμ. Whenμ\muμdecreases, which of the following changes could prevent the car from slipping away on this roundabout?\hspace{1em}Banking angle of the turn\hspace{1em}\hspace{3em}Speed of the car\hspace{3em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}increaseincrease\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}decreaseincrease\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}increasedecrease\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}decreasedecrease
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Whenμ\muμdecreases, the maximum possible frictional force decreases. Friction acts along with the component of the normal force in the horizontal direction to produce the centripetal force. To account for this change, decreasing the speed will allow the car to require less frictional force due to a lower required centripetal acceleration and safely take the turn.mv2r=μmg\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=\mu mgrmv2​=μmgIncreasing the banking angle increases the component of the normal force that points towards the centre of the circle, providing more centripetal force to compensate for the loss in centripetal force contribution from friction. Remember that in this situation friction is acting towards the centre of the circle, and so having an increased component of the normal force acting towards the centre of the circle will‘\lq‘help' friction to turn the car.

list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:At the top positionT+W=FcentripetalT + W=F_{centripetal}T+W=Fcentripetal​andT=0T = 0T=0Therefore,Fcentripetal=WF_{centripetal} = WFcentripetal​=WAt the bottomT−W=FcentripetalT - W  =  F_{centripetal}T−W=Fcentripetal​Since speed is constant:Fcentripetal=WF_{centripetal} = WFcentripetal​=WTherefore, the tension at the bottomT=2WT = 2WT=2W

list.title: Question 35
list.content:
A brick of weight100100100N rests on a rough horizontal surface. A varying horizontal force is applied to the brick. The graph shows the variation of the magnitude of the frictional force with the magnitude of the applied force.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/64067065-6e8b-4d0c-843f-45ceb9e213b9/images/b43d2c76-cb43-4b97-8113-985637836110/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.09.59%E2%80%AFPM.png)

list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The dynamic friction between two surfaces occurs when there is a relative motion between them. It has a fixed value and it can be found byFf=μdFNF_f=\mu_dF_NFf​=μd​FN​The graph shows the static friction force increasing linearly to a maxiumum until the object starts to slip and dynamic friction replaces static friction. According to the graph, the magnitude of the dynamic friction (the fixed value on the graph) is404040N.By consideringFg=FNF_g=F_NFg​=FN​We can substituteFN=100F_N=100FN​=100N andFf=40F_f=40Ff​=40N into the friction equation as follows:Ff=μdFNF_f=\mu_dF_NFf​=μd​FN​40N=μd40\,N=\mu_d40N=μd​(100 N)0.40=μd0.40=\mu_d0.40=μd​Therefore, the answer is C.

list.content: A box of weight400400400N is placed on a scale in an elevator. It is less than the weight, which means that the elevator is accelerating downwards.The weight of the box is given as400400400NMass can be found throughW=mgW=mgW=mg400=m(10)400 = m(10)400=m(10)m=40m=40m=40kgResolving the forces and using Newton's Second Law gives\hspace{1em}ΣF=ma\Sigma F = maΣF=ma\hspace{1em}400−300=(40)a400-300=(40)a400−300=(40)a\hspace{1em}a=2.5a=2.5a=2.5m s−2^{-2}−2

list.title: Question 37
list.content:
A ball of mass 0.5 kg moving horizontally strikes a vertical wall with a speed of 30 m s−1^{-1}−1. The magnitude of the change of the momentum of the ball is 22.5 kg m s−1^{-1}−1. Calculate the speed of the ball just after it rebounds.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8425ea05-2617-4ded-b0e9-edb297fa635a/images/d1c76c1d-7e5f-4b4f-b398-e74b073c46a5/PH0247.png)

A.\hspace{1em}0 m s−1^{-1}−1B.\hspace{1em}5 m s−1^{-1}−1C.\hspace{1em}10 m s−1^{-1}−1D.\hspace{1em}15 m s−1^{-1}−1
list.markScheme:
DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Change in momentum;Δp=pf−pi\Delta p = p_f - p_iΔp=pf​−pi​The momentum in the left direction is regarded as negative while the right is positive. Therefore;−Δp=−pf−pi−Δp=−mv−mu−22.5=−0.5v−(0.5)(30)0.5v=22.5−150.5v=7.5v=15m s−1\begin{aligned}
\hspace{0.8
cm}-\Delta p &= -p_f - p_i\\
-\Delta p &= -mv - mu\\
-22.5 &= -0.5v - (0.5)(30)\\
0.5v &= 22.5 - 15\\
0.5v &= 7.5\\
v &= 15\textrm{ m s}^{-1}
\end{aligned}−Δp−Δp−22.50.5v0.5vv​=−pf​−pi​=−mv−mu=−0.5v−(0.5)(30)=22.5−15=7.5=15m s−1​

\hspace{1em}C.D.

list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:According to Newton’s First Law, when the resultant force acting on the object is zero, acceleration will be zero and the velocity of the object is constant.  When head to tail method is applied to add the three vectors of option C, the following is obtained.

The closed triangle represents a resultant force of zero.Hence, the correct answer is C.

list.title: Question 39
list.content:
An egg hits a wall covered with a soft material and sticks to it. The graph shows the variation of horizontal forceFFFacting on the egg with timetttduring the collision.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c58a3655-499a-4418-8936-9ffbdcad1b75/images/ee6eba17-bae2-471b-bcae-5d464a02e193/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.31.57%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

The soft material on the wall is removed and an identical egg with the same initial speed collides with and sticks to the wall. Which graph shows the variation of horizontal forceFFFacting on the second egg with timetttduring the collision?  The graph for the first egg is shown as a dotted line.A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c58a3655-499a-4418-8936-9ffbdcad1b75/images/b5075853-1b1f-472d-aead-c9bfe18c774d/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.32.39o%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

\hspace{1cm}

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c58a3655-499a-4418-8936-9ffbdcad1b75/images/b3bbeb20-fd49-439b-a4b3-1ac892f72c3d/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.32.44%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

\hspace{1em}C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c58a3655-499a-4418-8936-9ffbdcad1b75/images/03ad81b3-f121-4564-83dd-4c55450dd162/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.32.48%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c58a3655-499a-4418-8936-9ffbdcad1b75/images/a2b278fe-7a8f-4e28-a65d-071c6595dcd5/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.32.52%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Due to colliding with a hard surface instead of a soft surface, the time for the collision will be much less. Since the egg hits the wall with the same velocity and stops in both situations, the change in momentum of the egg is the same for both collisions. The area under a force-time graph gives the change in momentum for an object. Thus the areas under the graphs should be equal.By using Newton’s second lawFavg=ΔpΔtF_{avg}=\Delta p\Delta tFavg​=ΔpΔtΔt=ΔpFavg\Delta t = \dfrac{\Delta p}{F_{avg}}Δt=Favg​Δp​According to this relationship, a shorter time of collision will result in a greater average force and also greater peak force. This is shown in graph A.

list.title: Question 40
list.content:
The diagram below shows a person of mass 80 kg standing in an elevator of mass 800 kg. The elevator accelerates upwards at a rate of 1.2 m s−2^{-2}−2.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f33b5a1c-0d63-4e7e-b7c5-585e9bd20232/images/7092be56-0665-4bb1-9771-f5bf4603bece/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.46.12%E2%80%AFAM.png)

What is the normal contact force exerted on the person by the elevator?A.\hspace{1em}96 NB.\hspace{1em}690 NC.\hspace{1em}780 ND.\hspace{1em}880 N
list.markScheme:
DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:There are two forces acting on the person - Weight and normal contact force. The lift is accelerating upwards so there must be a net force upwards.  Below is a free body diagram showing these forces.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f33b5a1c-0d63-4e7e-b7c5-585e9bd20232/images/744a0134-dee2-4a34-a2e2-0bcb76f19d03/PH0932Ans.png)

Net force =mamamaNormal contact force−-−Weight =mamamaNormal contact force =mg+ma=m(g+a)=80(9.8+1.2)=80(11)=880mg + ma = m(g + a) = 80(9.8 + 1.2) = 80(11) = 880mg+ma=m(g+a)=80(9.8+1.2)=80(11)=880NFurther intuition‾\underline{\textrm{Further intuition}}Further intuition​:The normal contact force is the upward force felt by the person in the elevator. The person will feel heavier when the elevator is accelerating upwards.Normal contact force =m(g+a)m(g+a)m(g+a)will be true for anyaaaif we take upwards acceleration as positive.Examples:‾\underline{\textrm{Examples:}}Examples:​Whena=0a = 0a=0(the elevator is stationary), normal contact force =mgmgmgWhenaaais negative (the elevator is accelerating downwards) normal contact force =m(g−a)m(g - a)m(g−a)Whena=−ga = -ga=−g(elevator is in freefall) normal contact force = 0

list.title: Question 41
list.content:
A roller coaster passes a vertical loop in a constant gravitational field. Friction and air resistance are negligible.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f9fbca55-1d2f-4718-ad75-58d48d2e356d/images/0cf089b7-2bb6-4ec1-80b9-460ea82b2837/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.26.41%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

How do the kinetic energy of the roller coaster and the normal reaction force acting on the roller coaster compare at point X and Y?\hspace{1.75em}kinetic energy\hspace{1.75em}\hspace{1em}normal reaction force\hspace{1em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}greater at X than Ygreater at Y than X\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}greater at Y than Xgreater at X than Y\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}greater at Y than Xgreater at Y than X\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}greater at X than Ygreater at X than Y
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:By conservation of energy, the roller coaster has greater kinetic energy at the bottom of the loop (X), then kinetic energy is converted to gravitational potential energy at the top of the loop (Y). Hence B and C are rejected.The normal reaction force by the track contributes to the centripetal force needed for the roller coaster to move along the loop. Since centripetal force increases with speed, the normal reaction force is larger at the bottom of the loop (X), when speed is greater. At the bottom of the loop, the normal reaction force is also the sum of the centripetal force and the weight of the roller coaster, while at the top of the loop the centripetal force is normal force is equal to the centripetal force minus the gravitational force.

list.title: Question 42
list.content:
An object of massmmmrests on a rough surface. Another object of massMMMis connected to it with a rope.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5e1a53fc-8a87-47ba-a519-cfe28bebbadc/images/6c42ecf6-21ee-4fb7-a6b8-4bbfd1f21450/PH0541-1.png)

The image below shows the free-body diagram of horizontal forces on the object of massmmm.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5e1a53fc-8a87-47ba-a519-cfe28bebbadc/images/803b1ee4-7847-4dcb-abd1-2fa5525ae946/PH0541-2.png)

Which of the following correctly describes the Newton's 3rd Law force paired withF2F_2F2​?A.\hspace{1em}The pull of massmmmupwards on the earth.B.\hspace{1em}The upward contact force acting on the massmmm.C.\hspace{1em}The tension force to the right acting on the massmmm.D.\hspace{1em}The friction force to the right acting on the surface.
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:According to the given diagram, two horizontal forces are acting on the massmmm. They are friction and tension. The force acting towards the left, represented byF2F_2F2​, is friction. The friction occurs on the object due to sliding on the surface. Therefore, according to Newton's third law, the pair of the force must be on the surface and in the opposite direction. Therefore, the answer is D.

list.title: Question 43
list.content: A trolley is pushed in a level parking area of a market on a very rainy day. The rain fills the trolley at a rate ofRRRkg s−1^{-1}−1. Ignoring frictional forces, what is the force needed to move the trolley at a constant speed ofvvv?A.Rv\hspace{1em}  	\ R vRvB.Rv\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{R}{v}vR​C.vR\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{v}{R}Rv​D.R+v\hspace{1em}  	R+vR+v
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:As water enters the trolley, a force is needed to increase the water’s horizontal momentum so that it is moving at the same speed as the trolley.We are given that the rate at which the water enters the trolley isRRR, soR=ΔmΔtR=\dfrac{\Delta m}{\Delta t}R=ΔtΔm​The force F acting on the trolley:F=ΔpΔtF=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}F=ΔtΔp​F=Δ(mv)ΔtF=\dfrac{\Delta (mv)}{\Delta t}F=ΔtΔ(mv)​Sincevvvis constant,F=vΔmΔtF=v \dfrac{\Delta m}{\Delta t} \hspace{2em}F=vΔtΔm​whereΔmΔt=R\hspace{2em}\dfrac{\Delta m}{\Delta t}=RΔtΔm​=RF=RvF=R vF=Rv

list.title: Question 44
list.content:
A box with a mass of M rests on a balance in an elevator that is moving downwards. The elevator slows with an acceleration ofg4\dfrac{g}{4}4g​.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7dab1f3-5df3-4e27-9cbf-cd571f4fa49c/images/668949a1-7b88-4532-bf3c-3689bdf6f746/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.23.51%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Which of the following gives the reading of the balance?A.5Mg4\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{5Mg}{4}45Mg​B.Mg\hspace{1em}  	MgMgC.3Mg4\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{3Mg}{4}43Mg​D.Mg2\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{Mg}{2}2Mg​
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The reading of the balance is equal to the magnitude of the reaction force. The free-body diagram of the box M:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7dab1f3-5df3-4e27-9cbf-cd571f4fa49c/images/93aad0fb-70d9-4742-9503-89c79a83c9b5/PH0543-2.png)

Since the elevator slows down downwards, the acceleration must be upwards and the normal reaction force (FN)F_N)FN​)must be greater than the weight (FgF_gFg​). According to Newton’s Second Law, the following relationship can be written:FN−Fg=maF_N - F_g = maFN​−Fg​=maWhen the given expressions are substituted:FN−Mg=M(g4)F_N - Mg=M\bigg(\dfrac{g}{4}\bigg)FN​−Mg=M(4g​)FN=M(g4)+MgF_N = M\bigg(\dfrac{g}{4}\bigg)+MgFN​=M(4g​)+MgFN=5Mg4F_N = \dfrac{5Mg}{4}FN​=45Mg​Therefore, the answer is A.

list.title: Question 45
list.content:
Two blocks of massesmmmand2m2m2mapproach each other and collide on a horizontal smooth surface. After the collision, they move together. The speeds of the blocks before the collision are5v5v5vand2v2v2vas shown.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f19e4d29-0626-4d4e-860f-091ac4774da8/images/e2a5e8eb-26c4-4918-8298-bcc5c293080c/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.36.05%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Which of the following correctly gives the speed of the blocks after the collision and the nature of the collision?Speed after collisionNature of collision\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}3v3v3vElastic\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}v3\dfrac{v}{3}3v​Elastic\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}3v3v3vInelastic\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}v3\dfrac{v}{3}3v​Inelastic
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:According to the principle of conservation of momentum, the total momentum before the collision equals the total momentum after the collision.As the blocks are moving in opposite directions, a sign convention is introduced where motion to the right is positive.pinitial=pfinalp_{initial} = p_{final}pinitial​=pfinal​m(5v)+2m(−2v)=3mvfm(5v)+2m\left(-2v\right)=3mv_fm(5v)+2m(−2v)=3mvf​wherevfv_fvf​is the speed of the blocks after the collisionmv=3mvfmv=3mv_fmv=3mvf​v3=vf\dfrac{v}{3}=v_f3v​=vf​The initial total kinetic energy of the blocks before the collisionEkiE_{ki}Eki​:Eki=12m(5v)2+122m(2v)2E_{ki}=\dfrac{1}{2}m{(5v)}^2+\dfrac{1}{2}2m{(2v)}^2Eki​=21​m(5v)2+21​2m(2v)2Eki=12(33mv2)E_{ki}=\dfrac{1}{2}(33mv^2)Eki​=21​(33mv2)The total kinetic energy of the blocks after the collisionEkfE_{kf}Ekf​:Ekf=12(3m)(v3)2E_{kf}=\dfrac{1}{2}(3m){\bigg(\dfrac{v}{3}\bigg)}^2Ekf​=21​(3m)(3v​)2Ekf=16mv2E_{kf}=\dfrac{1}{6}mv^2Ekf​=61​mv2The total kinetic energy is conserved in elastic collisions while it is not conserved in inelastic collisions.  Since the total kinetic energy before the collision is less than the total kinetic energy of the blocks after the collision, the collision is inelastic.(In any collision where objects “stick together” the situation is an inelastic collision.)

list.title: Question 46
list.content:
A solid sphere of massmmmis released from rest below the surface of oil and moves downwards.Draw the free body diagram of the sphere at the instant it was released.[2]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0eb89091-7544-4714-b967-648688309f05/images/5abc5ee9-e827-4a82-8625-f76a3d1c9c85/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.33.43%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Show that the terminal speed of the sphere is given by:v=2r2g(ρs−ρo)9ηv=\dfrac{2r^2 g(\rho_s-\rho_o)}{9\eta}v=9η2r2g(ρs​−ρo​)​whereρs\rho_sρs​is the density of the sphere andρo\rho_oρo​is the density of oil.[2]Another sphere from the same material but with mass8m8m8mreleased in the oil. Determine the terminal velocity of the new sphere in terms of the terminal velocity of the smaller sphere,vvv.[3]
list.markScheme:
Weight downwards and buoyant force upwards✓\checkmark✓Weight arrow is longer than the buoyant force arrow.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The sphere is accelerating downwards. This is because the gravitational force on the sphere is bigger than the buoyant force. Note that at the instant of release, the is no velocity and therefore no drag force.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0eb89091-7544-4714-b967-648688309f05/images/6b72ec4a-a248-4bff-903d-3f6c8ffa03fc/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%204.44.43%E2%80%AFPM.png)

mg=ρoVg+6πηrvmg=\rho_o Vg+6\pi \eta rvmg=ρo​Vg+6πηrv✓\checkmark✓Correct steps to reachv=2r2g(ρs−ρo)9ηv=\dfrac{2r^2 g(\rho_s-\rho_o)}{9\eta}v=9η2r2g(ρs​−ρo​)​✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​When the sphere reaches terminal speed, its weight is equal to the sum of the buoyant and drag forces.Fg=Fb+FdF_g=F_b+F_dFg​=Fb​+Fd​mg=ρoVg+6πηrvmg=\rho_o Vg+6\pi \eta rvmg=ρo​Vg+6πηrvρsVg=ρoVg+6πηrv\rho_s Vg=\rho_o Vg+6\pi \eta rvρs​Vg=ρo​Vg+6πηrvv=ρsVg−ρoVg6πηrv=\dfrac{\rho_s Vg-\rho_o Vg}{6\pi \eta r}v=6πηrρs​Vg−ρo​Vg​v=Vg(ρs−ρo)6πηrv=\dfrac{Vg(\rho_s-\rho_o)}{6\pi \eta r}v=6πηrVg(ρs​−ρo​)​v=43πr3g(ρs−ρo)6πηrv=\dfrac{\frac{4}{3}\pi r^3 g(\rho_s-\rho_o)}{6\pi \eta r}v=6πηr34​πr3g(ρs​−ρo​)​v=2r2g(ρs−ρo)9ηv=\dfrac{2r^2 g(\rho_s-\rho_o)}{9\eta}v=9η2r2g(ρs​−ρo​)​r2=2rr_2=2rr2​=2r✓\checkmark✓v∝r2v \propto r^2v∝r2✓\checkmark✓v2=4vv_2=4vv2​=4v✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Since the new sphere is from the same material as that in part (b) (i), then:m2V2=mV\dfrac{m_2}{V_2} = \dfrac{m}{V}V2​m2​​=Vm​8mV2=mV\dfrac{8m}{V_2} = \dfrac{m}{V}V2​8m​=Vm​V2=8VV_2=8VV2​=8V(r2)3=8r3(r_2)^3=8r^3(r2​)3=8r3r2=2rr_2=2rr2​=2rFrom the relation in (b)(i)v∝r2v \propto r^2v∝r2Thenv2=4vv_2=4vv2​=4v

list.title: Question 47
list.content:
A ball of mass 100 g hits the ground at an angle of45°45\degree45°and a speed of 10 m s−1^{-1}−1. The collision is elastic, and the ball makes contact with the ground for a total time of 100 ms. This is illustrated below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f72f77f-7ad8-483e-b91e-8dfeb4cb15c2/images/99fe19b1-7971-4531-bcfc-196700e2ddb3/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.03.13%E2%80%AFPM.png)

What is the magnitude of the average net force on the ball during the collision?A.\hspace{1em}7.17.17.1NB.\hspace{1em}101010NC.\hspace{1em}141414ND.\hspace{1em}202020N
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Fnet=ΔpΔt=mΔvΔtF_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{m\Delta v}{\Delta t}Fnet​=ΔtΔp​=ΔtmΔv​The horizontal component of the speed/momentum of the object does not change - the force exerted by ground is purely vertical.Initial and final vertical velocities are−10sin⁡(45°)-10\sin{(45\degree)}−10sin(45°)and +10sin⁡(45°)10\sin{(45\degree)}10sin(45°)if we take upwards as the positive direction (this will give a positive force as the direction of the force exerted by the ground on the ball is upwards) see diagram below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f72f77f-7ad8-483e-b91e-8dfeb4cb15c2/images/67e50acf-d004-4a7b-b955-05573f43c304/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.07.40%E2%80%AFPM.png)

For the vertical directionΔv=\Delta v=Δv=final velocity−-−initial velocity=10sin⁡45°−(−10sin⁡45°)=10sin⁡45°+10sin⁡45°=20sin⁡45°=10\sin{45\degree}-(-10\sin{45\degree})=10\sin{45\degree}+10\sin{45\degree}=20\sin{45\degree}=10sin45°−(−10sin45°)=10sin45°+10sin45°=20sin45°Fnet=mΔvΔt=(0.1)(20sin⁡45°)0.1=20sin⁡45°F_{net}=\dfrac{m\Delta v}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{(0.1)(20\sin{45\degree})}{0.1}=20\sin{45\degree}Fnet​=ΔtmΔv​=0.1(0.1)(20sin45°)​=20sin45°= 14 N(Here we have converted to SI units 100 g = 0.1 kg and 100 ms = 0.1 s)

list.title: Question 48
list.content:
A ball is tied to a1010\,10cm rope and rotates in a horizontal circular path starting from point X with a linear speed of 20 cm s−1^{-1}−1. The rope is cut after 2 s, at which time the object is at point Y as shown in the diagram.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/270e4c90-9a2f-4eb0-9f73-d5b8c6206f04/images/9ffc6634-7ca7-40f1-9f4d-ea886a8b6cf6/PH0638oo.png)

Which of the following is correct about the angular displacement of the ball betweenXXXandYYYand the direction of motion of the ball after the rope is cut?Angular DisplacementDirection of Motion\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}2 rad

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/270e4c90-9a2f-4eb0-9f73-d5b8c6206f04/images/5210521f-2b91-4706-9211-fb6c0774b8cc/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.53.36%E2%80%AFPM.png)

\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}2 rad

\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}4 rad

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/270e4c90-9a2f-4eb0-9f73-d5b8c6206f04/images/fc39ccb2-72d4-4f75-8e6e-83e5be9cc95f/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.53.55%E2%80%AFPM.png)

\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}4 rad

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/270e4c90-9a2f-4eb0-9f73-d5b8c6206f04/images/696bb73f-ee37-47b5-8949-d432806f9ae9/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.54.07%E2%80%AFPM.png)
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Note that although the direction is not stated in the question, from determining the angular displacement, the direction it is traveling can be determined.\hspace{1em}ω=vr\omega=\dfrac{v}{r}ω=rv​\hspace{1em}ω=2010=\omega=\dfrac{20}{10}=ω=1020​=2 rad s−1^{-1}−1\hspace{1em}ω=ΔθΔt\omega =\dfrac{\Delta \theta}{\Delta t}ω=ΔtΔθ​\hspace{1em}Δθ=ωΔt=(2)(2)=4\Delta \theta = \omega \Delta t = (2)(2) = 4Δθ=ωΔt=(2)(2)=4radBecause one full circle is2π2 \pi2πradians, we can see thatΔθ\Delta \thetaΔθis approximately23\dfrac{2}{3}32​of a full circle. Therefore, it must be moving clockwise around the circle. This allows us to determine that the tangential velocity at that point in time must be up and to the right.

list.title: Question 49
list.content: An airplane of weightWWWis flying horizontally with constant velocity. The total forward thrust of the engines is3W3W3W. Which of the following gives the magnitude of the force of the air on the plane?A.4W\hspace{1em} 4W4WB.3W\hspace{1em} 3W3WC.\hspace{1em}10W\sqrt{10}W10​WD.\hspace{1em}8W\sqrt{8} W8​W

For the large mass, which expressions are correct for the force of frictionFf_ff​and the normal forceFN_NN​?\hspace{3em}Ff_ff​\hspace{3em}\hspace{4em}FN_NN​\hspace{4em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}mgcos⁡θmg \cos\thetamgcosθMg−mgsin⁡θMg - mg \sin\thetaMg−mgsinθ\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}mgsin⁡θmg \sin \thetamgsinθMg−mgsin⁡θMg - mg \sin\thetaMg−mgsinθ\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}mgsin⁡θmg \sin \thetamgsinθMg−mgcos⁡θMg - mg \cos\thetaMg−mgcosθ\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}mgcos⁡θmg \cos\thetamgcosθMg−mgcos⁡θMg - mg \cos\thetaMg−mgcosθ

list.title: Question 62
list.content: A pointPPPis subjected to three simultaneous forces of magnitudesFA>FB>FCF_A > F_B > F_CFA​>FB​>FC​. PointPPPis in equilibrium. Consider of the following statements.I.FA=FB+FCF_A = F_B + F_CFA​=FB​+FC​II.FA≤FB+FCF_A \leq F_B + F_CFA​≤FB​+FC​III.FA>FB−FCF_A > F_B - F_CFA​>FB​−FC​Which of the statements isnot always trueabout the magnitudes of the forces?A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}II and III only
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Vectors of forces in equilibrium form a triangle or a straight line.The sum of two sides of a triangle is always greater than the third (II is always true).The difference between two sides of a triangle is always less than the third (III is also always true).I is trueonly whenthe three forces are in a straight line andFBF_BFB​andFCF_CFC​are both opposingFAF_AFA​(not always true, as required by the question).

The radial forceFFFof the rod is constant.What is the ratio of the linear speed at the top to the linear speed at the bottom of its path,vtopvbottom\dfrac{v_{top}}{v_{bottom}}vbottom​vtop​​?A.\hspace{1em}F−mgF+mg\dfrac{F-mg}{F+mg}F+mgF−mg​B.\hspace{1em}F+mgF−mg\dfrac{F+mg}{F-mg}F−mgF+mg​C.\hspace{1em}F−mgF+mg\sqrt{\dfrac{F-mg}{F+mg}}F+mgF−mg​​D.\hspace{1em}F+mgF−mg\sqrt{\dfrac{F+mg}{F-mg}}F−mgF+mg​​

list.title: Question 65
list.content:
A car enters a horizontal circular roundabout as shown with a speed of 35 km h−1^{-1}−1. The radius of the roundabout is 15 m.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ae5d5d2c-d886-4aa8-875e-97c202da73d1/images/678c565e-beaf-419e-8ae6-5608f15c2ecf/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%201.32.11%E2%80%AFPM.png)

State the force which provides the centripetal force for the circular motion of the car.[1]Calculate the minimum coefficient of static friction between the tyres of the car and the road for the car to safely complete its motion around the roundabout.[3]State and explain any change in your answer to part (b) if:The mass of the car increases.[2]The road is banked at an angle so that the car is tilted towards the center of the roundabout.[2]The speed of the car increases.[2]
list.markScheme: Frictionalforce (between the road and the car tyres)✓\checkmark✓Weight is not accepted as a response here.Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:It is the force of friction between the road and the tires that provides the force towards the centre of the roundabout. Without friction, the car would not be able to make the turn.The speed of the car is (35km h−135\textrm{ km h}^{-1}35km h−1, which is35000m3600s)=\dfrac{35000\textrm{ m}}{3600\textrm{ s}})=3600s35000m​)=9.72 m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓Frictional force provides the centripetal force, thereforemv2r=mgμ\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=mg\murmv2​=mgμRearranging givesμ=v2rg\mu=\dfrac{v^2}{rg}μ=rgv2​✓\checkmark✓ORThe substitution:μ=9.722(15)(9.8)\mu=\dfrac{9.72^2}{(15)(9.8)}μ=(15)(9.8)9.722​=0.64✓\checkmark✓(2 marks max if speed is not converted to m s−1^{-1}−1. This gives 8.33)No change✓\checkmark✓The mass of the car impacts the calculation of the frictional force and centripetal force equally/cancels in the calculation.✓\checkmark✓Decrease✓\checkmark✓The normal force would contribute to the centripetal force, therefore less frictional force would be sufficient.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:On a banked turn, the normal force will have a component that points towards the centre of the circle. As the centripetal force required is the same as on a non-banked turn, less frictional force is required and therefore a lower coefficient of friction is sufficient.Increase✓\checkmark✓At a higher speed, a larger centripetal force would be necessary to maintain the circular motion.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:A higher speed will increase the value ofmv2r\dfrac{mv^2}{r}rmv2​, resulting in the need for a higher value for the coefficient of frictionμ\muμ.

list.title: Question 68
list.content:
An object of massmmmand initial velocityvvvcollides with a stationary object of mass2m2m2m.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f1971e54-30eb-442a-aa50-607973aad940/images/3fb732f1-87a9-449f-b833-c4c911243712/Screenshot%202025-03-25%20at%207.24.54%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

After the collision the object of mass2m2m2mmoves with velocity2v3\dfrac{2v}{3}32v​.  What is the final velocity of the object of massmmmand the magnitude of impulse of the collision?Final velocity of mass\textrm{Final velocity of mass}Final velocity of massmmm\hspace{1.5em}Impulse\textrm{Impulse}Impulse\hspace{1.5em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}−v3\dfrac{-v}{3}3−v​2mv3\dfrac{2mv}{3}32mv​\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}−v3\dfrac{-v}{3}3−v​4mv3\dfrac{4mv}{3}34mv​\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}v3\dfrac{v}{3}3v​2mv3\dfrac{2mv}{3}32mv​\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}v3\dfrac{v}{3}3v​4mv3\dfrac{4mv}{3}34mv​
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Using conservation of momentum, we set the initial momentum equal of the system equal to the final momentum. We can represent the final velocity of the object of massmmmasvfmv_{fm}vfm​. Applying the law of conservation of momentum givesmv=mvfm+2m(2v3)mv=mv_{fm}+2m\left(\dfrac{2v}{3}\right)mv=mvfm​+2m(32v​)v=vfm+2(2v3)v=v_{fm}+2\left(\dfrac{2v}{3}\right)v=vfm​+2(32v​)vfm=v−4v3=−v3v_{fm}=v-\dfrac{4v}{3}=\dfrac{-v}{3}vfm​=v−34v​=3−v​The negative sign represents the fact that the smaller mass will bounce backwards in the collision.ImpulseJJJis equal to change in momentum.J=mΔvJ=m\Delta vJ=mΔvThe simplest way to find the impulse of this collision is to consider the change in momentum of the ball that is initially stationary.J=mΔv=2m(2v3−0)=4mv3J=m\Delta v=2m\left(\dfrac{2v}{3}-0\right)=\dfrac{4mv}{3}J=mΔv=2m(32v​−0)=34mv​

list.content:
A stationary object explodes and splits into two parts of massesmmmand2m2m2m. Massmmmmoves north with a velocity of2v2v2vand mass2m2m2mmoves south with a velocity ofvvv. Calculate the total change in linear momentum of the system as a result of the explosion.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ff2acbba-2403-4a67-b180-9dbd6ab500fe/images/84602be2-5f8f-4366-be5d-8b3dd6c7f170/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.56.30%E2%80%AFPM.png)

A.\hspace{1em}ZeroB.\hspace{1em}1.5mv1.5mv1.5mvC.\hspace{1em}4mv4mv4mvD.\hspace{1em}6mv6mv6mv
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The change in the momentum of the system in the explosion is zero, as the system is isolated and therefore momentum is conserved.

list.title: Question 72
list.content: A firecracker is at rest just before exploding. Upon exploding, the firecracker splits into two unequal parts which are projected in exactly opposite directions. Which of the following must be true?A.\hspace{1em}The total kinetic energy of the firecracker remains unchanged before and after the explosion.B.\hspace{1em}The kinetic energy of the two parts after the explosion is identical.C.\hspace{1em}The total momentum of the firecracker is unchanged after the explosion.D.\hspace{1em}The velocities of the two parts are exactly equal in magnitude but opposite in direction.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:A. Incorrect. BecauseEkE_kEk​changed from zero to non-zero because the chemical potential energy in the firecracker is converted into kinetic energy which is divided between the two parts after the explosion.B. Incorrect. BecauseEk=(p22m)E_k=\left(\dfrac{p^2}{2m}\right)Ek​=(2mp2​)and the momenta must be equal, the kinetic energies must be unequal as the masses are not equal.C. Correct. Momentum is always conserved in any process for an isolated system.D. Incorrect. Because since momentum is conserved, unequal parts must have unequal velocities.

list.title: Question 73
list.content:
An object of massmmmrests on a rough surface. Another object of massMMMis connected to it via a frictionless pulley. The coefficient of dynamic friction between the surface and the object of massmmmisμ\muμ.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/05d91a08-8de6-402e-8cdc-523e298b8e9e/images/3cc24a0e-924d-46a5-9506-bc8a67c37f66/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%201.47.48%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

When the object of massMMMis released, the objects accelerate. What is the acceleration of the system?A.\hspace{1em}gMM+m\dfrac{gM}{M+m}M+mgM​B.\hspace{1em}gmM+m\dfrac{gm}{M+m}M+mgm​C.\hspace{1em}g(M−μm)M+m\dfrac{g(M-\mu m)}{M+m}M+mg(M−μm)​D.\hspace{1em}g(μm−M)M+m\dfrac{g(\mu m-M)}{M+m}M+mg(μm−M)​
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The resultant force is the difference between the weight of the object of massMMMand the force of friction between the object of massmmmand the rough surface.Fnet=Fg−Ff=mtotalaF_{net} = F_g - F_f =m_{total}aFnet​=Fg​−Ff​=mtotal​aWeight of the objectFg=MgF_g= MgFg​=MgFriction on massmmmFf=μmgF_f= \mu mgFf​=μmgMtotal=M+mM_{total}=M+mMtotal​=M+mSubstituting into the first equation,Mg−μmg=(M+m)aMg - \mu mg = (M+m)aMg−μmg=(M+m)aBy rearranging;a=g(M−μm)M+ma = \dfrac{g(M-\mu m)}{M+m}a=M+mg(M−μm)​Therefore, The answer is C.

list.title: Question 74
list.content:
A system that consists of two light identical springs connected in series stores a total elastic potential energyEpE_pEp​when a load is added to the springs. One of the springs is then removed and the same load is added to the remaining spring.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/33f5116a-a5fd-45d6-9813-47893ca89f34/images/673d5011-a1de-4871-a58f-ca4a34260938/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.13.46%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]}}[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]In terms ofEpE_pEp​, what is the total elastic potential energy stored in the single spring situation?A.\hspace{1em}2EpE_pEp​B.\hspace{1em}EpE_pEp​C.\hspace{1em}0.5EpE_pEp​D.\hspace{1em}0.25EpE_pEp​
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Using Hooke's law,F=kΔxF=k\Delta xF=kΔxthe elastic potential energy isEp=12kΔx2=12FΔxE_p=\dfrac{1}{2} k\Delta x^2=\dfrac{1}{2} F\Delta xEp​=21​kΔx2=21​FΔx.In the two-spring situation, both springs have an extension given by the equationF=kΔxF=k\Delta xF=kΔx.When one of the springs is removed, the load remains unchanged and the remaining spring experiences the same extension. Therefore the elastic potential energy stored is also halved.

list.title: Question 75
list.content:
Two blocks of masses 3.0 kg and 4.0 kg are held stationary with a thread connecting the blocks. The mass of 3.0 kg is on a rough incline that makes an angle of 30° with the ground and it starts to slip up when the other mass is slightly more than 4.0 kg.

State two differences between static friction and dynamic friction[2]Calculate the coefficient of static friction between the mass of 3.0 kg and the rough surface.[3]The thread connecting masses breaks and the mass of 3.0 kg slides down. Show that the acceleration of the mass of 3.0 kg is around 1.5 m s−2^{-2}−2. The coefficient of dynamic friction between 3.0 kg mass and the rough surface is 0.40.[2]Determine the speed of the mass of 3.0 kg after it has moved through a vertical height of 1.0 m.[2]
list.markScheme:
Static friction occurs when the object is not moving (relative to a surface) and Dynamic friction occurs when there is relative motion between the object and a surface✓\checkmark✓The magnitude of static friction is dependent on external forces and the magnitude of dynamic friction is not dependent on external forcesORstatic friction force can vary up to a maximum while dynamic friction is a constant value✓\checkmark✓Component of weight parallel to the incline =≪mgsin⁡(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=≫15≪N≫\ll mg\sin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=\gg 15 \ll\textrm{N}\gg≪mgsin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=≫15≪N≫and tension in threadT=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39N✓\checkmark✓Static friction =≪39−15=≫24≪N≫\ll 39-15=\gg 24 \ll\textrm{N}\gg≪39−15=≫24≪N≫✓\checkmark✓coefficient of static friction =≪24(3.0)(9.81)cos⁡(30°)=≫\ll \dfrac{24}{(3.0)(9.81)\cos(30°)}= \gg≪(3.0)(9.81)cos(30°)24​=≫0.96✓\checkmark✓(0.94 to 0.96 accepted)Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:According to the diagram, the mass of 3 kg is balanced with weightWWW, tensionTTTstatic frictionFfF_fFf​and normal forceNNN;

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3e083eeb-2ac3-45c1-a54c-95d8955270d7/images/e14de16f-c457-499c-989c-258323ec83e0/PH0559Q.png)

Weight has two components parallel to the inclineWhW_hWh​and perpendicular to the inclineWvW_vWv​;Wh=mgsin⁡(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=15W_h=mg\sin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=15Wh​=mgsin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=15N down to the slopeThe tension balances the weight of the mass of 4.0 kg;T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39NThe forces parallel to the incline must cancel each other;Wh+Ff=T15+Ff=39Ff=24N\begin{aligned}
 W_h+F_f&=T\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 15+F_f&=39\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 F_f&=24\textrm{ N}\\
 \end{aligned}Wh​+Ff​15+Ff​Ff​​=T=39=24N​By using the equation of static friction;Ff=μRμ(3.0)(9.81)cos⁡(30°)=24μ=0.96\begin{aligned}
 F_f&=\mu R\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 \mu(3.0)(9.81)\cos(30°)&=24\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 \mu&=0.96\\
 \end{aligned}Ff​μ(3.0)(9.81)cos(30°)μ​=μR=24=0.96​The dynamic friction =≪μR=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)cos⁡30°=≫10≪N≫\ll\mu R=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)\cos30°=\gg 10 \ll N\gg≪μR=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)cos30°=≫10≪N≫✓\checkmark✓aaa=≪14.7−10.23=≫\ll\dfrac{14.7-10.2}{3}=\gg≪314.7−10.2​=≫1.5 m s−2^{-2}−2✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:There are only two forces that act on the mass parallel to the incline. They are components of the weightWhW_hWh​down to the slope and dynamic frictionFfF_fFf​up the slope. The dynamic friction;Ff=μR=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)cos⁡(30°)=10F_f=\mu R=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)\cos(30°)=10Ff​=μR=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)cos(30°)=10NFnet=maF_{net}=maFnet​=ma14.7−10.2=3.0a14.7-10.2=3.0a14.7−10.2=3.0aa=1.5a=1.5a=1.5m s−2^{-2}−2displacement of the mass =≪1.0sin⁡(30o)=≫2.0≪m≫\ll \dfrac{1.0}{\sin(30^o)} = \gg 2.0 \ll\textrm{m}\gg≪sin(30o)1.0​=≫2.0≪m≫✓\checkmark✓v=≪(2)(1.5)(2.0)=≫2.4≪m s−1≫v = \ll\sqrt{(2)(1.5)(2.0)}=\gg 2.4 \ll\textrm{m s}^{-1}\ggv=≪(2)(1.5)(2.0)​=≫2.4≪m s−1≫✓\checkmark✓ORHeat lost due to friction =≪Ffd=(10)(2.0)=≫20≪J≫\ll F_f d=(10)(2.0)=\gg 20\ll\textrm{J}\gg≪Ff​d=(10)(2.0)=≫20≪J≫✓\checkmark✓vvv=≪(2)(9.0)(3.0)=≫\ll \sqrt{\dfrac{(2)(9.0)}{(3.0)}}=\gg≪(3.0)(2)(9.0)​​=≫2.4 m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The overall displacement s of the mass when it displaced 1.0 m vertically;s=1.0sin⁡(30o)=2.0s=\dfrac{1.0}{\sin(30^o)}=2.0s=sin(30o)1.0​=2.0mBy using a suvat equation;v2=u2+2asv^2=u^2+2asv2=u2+2aswhileu=0u=0u=0,a=1.5a=1.5a=1.5m s−2^{-2}−2, ands=2.0s=2.0s=2.0mv2=(2)(1.5)(2.0)=6.0v^2=(2)(1.5)(2.0)=6.0v2=(2)(1.5)(2.0)=6.0v=2.4v=2.4v=2.4m s−1^{-1}−1This question can be also done with the conservation of energy approach;The energy dissipated due to friction isQ=Ffd=(10)(2)=20Q=F_f d=(10)(2)=20Q=Ff​d=(10)(2)=20Jand the change in gravitational potential energy can be found byΔEp=mgΔh=(3.0)(9.81)(1.0)=29\Delta E_p=mg\Delta h=(3.0)(9.81)(1.0)=29ΔEp​=mgΔh=(3.0)(9.81)(1.0)=29JThe gravitational potential energy was converted to thermal energy from friction and kinetic energy, therefore29=ΔEk+2029=\Delta E_k+2029=ΔEk​+20ΔEk=9.0\Delta E_k=9.0ΔEk​=9.0JSolving for speed givesΔEk=12mv2\Delta E_k=\frac{1}{2} mv^2ΔEk​=21​mv2v=2ΔEkmv=\sqrt{\dfrac{2\Delta E_k}{m}}v=m2ΔEk​​​v=(2)(9.0)(3.0)=2.4v=\sqrt{\dfrac{(2)(9.0)}{(3.0)}}=2.4v=(3.0)(2)(9.0)​​=2.4m s−1^{-1}−1

list.title: Question 77
list.content:
The rotor ride in the amusement park consists of a vertical cylinder that rotates around its axis. Its floor drops down when it rotates fast enough, so that a person inside it is held against its walls. The walls are made of rubberized material such that the coefficient of static frictionμ<1\mu <1μ<1.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bc818c3-b41c-4cb7-a344-ddead3976ef0/images/281ae2f3-a2fa-4ee9-a300-6c714b1e0255/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.40.27%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

[Source: Image created using Images by Clker-Free-Vector-Images from Pixabay - https://pixabay.com/]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Image created using Images by  Clker-Free-Vector-Images from Pixabay - https://pixabay.com/]}}[Source: Image created using Images by Clker-Free-Vector-Images from Pixabay - https://pixabay.com/]Explain in terms of forces how a person can remain suspended against the wall without falling when the floor is dropped.[3]Show that the maximum period of rotation for the person to remain at rest relative to the wall is given by\hspace{1em}T=4π2μrgT=\sqrt{\dfrac{4\pi^2\mu r}{g}}T=g4π2μr​​Whererrr= radius of the cylinderμ\muμ= coefficient of static friction between the wall and the person[3]The radius of the rotor is 4.5 m and the coefficient of static friction of the walls is 0.40.Calculate the angular speed of the cylinder necessary for this situation.[3]To make the ride more exciting, an idea of tilting the axis of the rotor by an angleθ\thetaθis discussed.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bc818c3-b41c-4cb7-a344-ddead3976ef0/images/a0617516-bba2-4b35-88e7-31ebb403eb3d/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.38.35%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

Draw and label the free body diagram of a person at pointAwhen the ride is in operation.[1]The cylinder is tilted a full 90°\degree°so that its axis of rotation is now horizontal. Deduce whether the minimum speed of rotation for this orientation is greater than or less than the minimum speed for the original situation with a vertical axis of rotation.[3]
list.markScheme:
The normal force provides the centripetal force,✓\checkmark✓Minimum speed is required / relation between normal force and linear speed.✓\checkmark✓Friction balances the weight.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The friction force of the wall on the person is affected by the normal force\hspace{1em}Ff=μFNF_f=\mu\ F_NFf​=μFN​The normal force of the walls in this situation is the centripetal force, which means it is affected by the linear velocity\hspace{1em}FN=Fc=mv2rF_N=F_c=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}FN​=Fc​=rmv2​This means that, there's a minimum speed at which the magnitude of the normal force will be enough so that the friction force of the walls will balance the weight of the person and keep it at rest without falling.The person's weight is in equilibrium with the friction force of the wall.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bc818c3-b41c-4cb7-a344-ddead3976ef0/images/e2ca7f98-5e73-47f7-bb08-885c0300b78c/PH0651aaaa.png)

\hspace{1.5em}Ff=μFN=μmv2rF_f=\mu\ F_N=\mu\dfrac{mv^2}{r}Ff​=μFN​=μrmv2​✓\checkmark✓Ff=mgF_f\ = mgFf​=mgthereforev2=rgμv^2=\dfrac{rg}{\mu}v2=μrg​✓\checkmark✓T=2πrvv2r=4π2rT2T=\dfrac{2\pi r}{v} \dfrac{v^2}{r} = \dfrac{4 \pi^{2r}}{T^2}T=v2πr​rv2​=T24π2r​✓\checkmark✓substitute and solve to get answer≪T=4π2μrg≫\ll\ T=\sqrt{\dfrac{4\pi^2\mu r}{g}}\gg≪T=g4π2μr​​≫Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The normal force is the centripetal forceFN=mv2rF_N=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}FN​=rmv2​And the friction force is given byFf=μFNF_f=\mu\ F_NFf​=μFN​ThenFf=μmv2rF_f=\mu\dfrac{mv^2}{r}Ff​=μrmv2​Since the friction force is in equilibrium with the weightFf=mgF_f=mgFf​=mgThen\hspace{1em}μmv2r=mgμv2r=gv2=rgμv=rgμ\begin{aligned}
\mu\frac{mv^2}{r}\ &=mg\\
\mu\frac{v^2}{r}\ &=g\\
v^2\ &=\frac{rg}{\mu}\\
v\ &=\sqrt{\frac{rg}{\mu}}\\
\end{aligned}μrmv2​μrv2​v2v​=mg=g=μrg​=μrg​​​Since the linear speed is given byv=2πrTv=\dfrac{2\pi r}{T}v=T2πr​ThenT=2πrv=2πrμrgT=\dfrac{2\pi r}{v}=2\pi\ r\sqrt{\dfrac{\mu}{rg}}T=v2πr​=2πrrgμ​​T=4π2μrgT=\sqrt{\dfrac{4\pi^2\mu r}{g}}T=g4π2μr​​ORSincev2r=4π2rT2\dfrac{v^2}{r}=\dfrac{4\pi^2r}{T^2}rv2​=T24π2r​ThenT2=4π2r2v2=4π2r2μrgT^2=\dfrac{4\pi^2r^2}{v^2}=\dfrac{4\pi^2r^2\mu}{rg}T2=v24π2r2​=rg4π2r2μ​T=4π2μrgT=\sqrt{\dfrac{4\pi^2\mu r}{g}}T=g4π2μr​​T=≪(4)(π2)(0.40)(4.5)(9.8)≫=2.69≪s≫T=\ll\sqrt{\dfrac{\left(4{)(\pi}^2\right)\left(0.40\right)\left(4.5\right)}{\left(9.8\right)}}\gg=2.69\ \ll\textrm{ s}\ggT=≪(9.8)(4)(π2)(0.40)(4.5)​​≫=2.69≪s≫✓\checkmark✓ω=≪2πT≫\omega=\ll\dfrac{2\pi}{T}\ggω=≪T2π​≫ω=2π2.69\omega=\dfrac{2\pi}{2.69}ω=2.692π​✓\checkmark✓ω=2.33≪rad s−1≫\omega=2.33\ \ll\textrm{ rad s}^{-1}\ggω=2.33≪rad s−1≫✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The angular speed is related to the linear speed byv=ωrv=\omega\ rv=ωrAndv=2πrTv=\dfrac{2\pi r}{T}v=T2πr​Thenω=2πT\omega=\dfrac{2\pi}{T}ω=T2π​SinceT=4π2μrg=(4)(π2)(0.40)(4.5)(9.8)=2.69T=\sqrt{\dfrac{4\pi^2\mu r}{g}}=\sqrt{\dfrac{\left(4{)(\pi}^2\right)\left(0.40\right)\left(4.5\right)}{\left(9.8\right)}}=2.69T=g4π2μr​​=(9.8)(4)(π2)(0.40)(4.5)​​=2.69sThenω=2π2.69=2.33\omega=\dfrac{2\pi}{2.69}=2.33ω=2.692π​=2.33rad s−1^{-1}−1Correct orientationANDlabelling of vectors.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bc818c3-b41c-4cb7-a344-ddead3976ef0/images/d79f0d1d-d21c-4838-8097-f4b718e5ff44/PH0651c_MS.png)

Horizontal axis of rotation:v2=rgv^2  = rgv2=rg✓\checkmark✓Vertical axis of rotation:v2=(rg)μv^2  = \dfrac{(rg)}{\mu}v2=μ(rg)​✓\checkmark✓μ<1\mu < 1μ<1,
therefore vertical minimum speed is greater than the horizontal minimum speed of rotation.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:For the horizontal axis of rotation, the minimum speed occurs when the centripetal acceleration at the top of the motion is equal to the acceleration due to gravity, resulting in a normal force of zero.v2r=g\dfrac{v^2}{r} = grv2​=gv2=rgv^2  = rgv2=rgFor the vertical axis,mv2r=FN\dfrac{mv^2}{r} = F_Nrmv2​=FN​FF=μFN=mgF_F = \mu F_N = mgFF​=μFN​=mgthereforeFN=mgμF_N= \dfrac{mg}{\mu}FN​=μmg​Which givesmv2r=mgμ\dfrac{mv^2}{r} = \dfrac{mg}{\mu}rmv2​=μmg​v2=(rg)μv^2  = \dfrac{(rg)}{\mu}v2=μ(rg)​Because the question states thatμ<1\mu < 1μ<1The minimum speed for the vertical rotational axis is greater than the minimum speed for the horizontal axis of rotation.

list.content:
The diagram shows the forces acting on a block as it slides down an inclined plane with constant acceleration.WWWis the weight of the block,FFFis the friction force,μd\mu_dμd​is the coefficient of dynamic friction andgggis the gravitational field strength. The plane is inclined at an angleθ\thetaθto the horizontal.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6dd9f02b-50c5-4738-bb6a-b711f780ca5f/images/0f6c937d-dd84-46b7-894a-f968f5aed254/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%203.55.44%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Which expression gives the acceleration of the block?A.\hspace{1em}gsin⁡θ−gμdcos⁡θg\sin\theta - g\mu_d\cos\thetagsinθ−gμd​cosθB.\hspace{1em}gcos⁡θ−gμdsin⁡θg\cos\theta - g\mu_d\sin\thetagcosθ−gμd​sinθC.\hspace{1em}Wsin⁡θ−Wμdcos⁡θW\sin\theta - W\mu_d\cos\thetaWsinθ−Wμd​cosθD.\hspace{1em}Wcos⁡θ−Wμdsin⁡θW\cos\theta - W\mu_d\sin\thetaWcosθ−Wμd​sinθ
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:To solve this, we should resolve the weight into componentsalong the slopeComponent of weight along the slope =mgsin⁡θmg\sin \thetamgsinθNormal reaction force (FNF_NFN​) is given bymgcos⁡θmg\cos\thetamgcosθDynamic friction =μdFN=μdmgcos⁡θ\mu_dF_N = \mu_d\,mg\cos \thetaμd​FN​=μd​mgcosθApply Newton's second law:Fnet=mgsin⁡θ−μdmgcos⁡θ=maF_{net}=mg\sin\theta - \mu_d\,mg\cos\theta =maFnet​=mgsinθ−μd​mgcosθ=maDividing both sides by mass givesa=gsin⁡θ−μdgcos⁡θa=g\sin\theta - \mu_d\,g\cos\thetaa=gsinθ−μd​gcosθ

list.title: Question 79
list.content:
Three identical cylinders sit inside a cup. Their radius of each is 5 cm and their centres of mass are marked in the diagram. The lines connecting the centres of the masses pass through the contact points between the cylinders.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c1073f-1058-406c-9d31-7ea31814fde3/images/28eb4292-7e34-4dd1-b84e-523fa72ba475/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%209.33.38%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

Draw and label the free-body diagram for the cylinderM3M_3M3​[2]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c1073f-1058-406c-9d31-7ea31814fde3/images/8ceca09c-66d6-413b-a0a3-dbab45457fbd/PH0560-A.png)

For analysis purposes, the three cylinders can at times be considered as a single object consisting of the mass of the all cylinders. Explain why this simplification may be useful.[1]The reaction force of the ground onM3M_3M3​is303030N. Show that the mass of each cylinder is around 1.0 kg.[2]Determine the force that massM3M_3M3​exerts onM1M_1M1​[2]
list.markScheme:
\hspace{1em}

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c1073f-1058-406c-9d31-7ea31814fde3/images/5079963b-144c-4400-ada3-9b1b31a00144/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%209.34.36%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

Correct direction and labeling of the forces✓\checkmark✓The reaction force of the ground is greater than the other forces✓\checkmark✓Interactions  between the cylinders can be ignored/it allows only external forces to be analyzed✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Every cylinder experiences forces due to their weights and forces from the other cylinders and the container walls. To decrease complexity in representing forces on the objects, the cylinders are simplified as combined to form one object so that forces between the cylinders can be ignored and only external forces can be considered.Total weight of the cylinder = reaction of the ground onM3M_3M3​Weight of each cylinder =303=10≪N≫\dfrac{30}{3}=10\ \ll\textrm{N}\gg330​=10≪N≫✓\checkmark✓m=≪109.81=≫m=\ll\dfrac{10}{9.81}=\ggm=≪9.8110​=≫1.02≪kg≫1.02\ \ll\textrm{kg}\gg1.02≪kg≫✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:When the three cylinders are considered as a single mass, the forces between the cylinders can be ignored. The vertical forces acting on the combined  masses are the weightWtW_tWt​of all discs and theRreaction force of the ground on theM3M_3M3​.Wt=RW_t=RWt​=RWt=30W_t=30Wt​=30NTherefore, the weight of one discWWWW=303=10W=\dfrac{30}{3}=10W=330​=10NSo, the massmmmof one discm=109.81=1.02m=\dfrac{10}{9.81}=1.02m=9.8110​=1.02kgThe weight of theM1M_1M1​is balanced by the vertical component of the force fromM3M_3M3​onM1M_1M1​✓\checkmark✓The reaction ofM3M_3M3​onM1=≪Wcos⁡θ=100.87=≫M_1=\ll\dfrac{W}{\cos\theta}=\dfrac{10}{0.87}=\ggM1​=≪cosθW​=0.8710​=≫11.5 N✓\checkmark✓ORReaction of theM3M_3M3​on theM1M_1M1​= Reaction of theM1M_1M1​on theM3M_3M3​ANDReaction of theM2M_2M2​on theM3M_3M3​= Reaction of theM1M_1M1​on theM3M_3M3​Reaction=≪N−W2(cos⁡θ)=30−10(2)(0.87)=≫11.5≪N≫\ll\dfrac{N-W}{2(\cos\theta)}=\dfrac{30-10\ }{\left(2\right)\left(0.87\right)}=\gg11.5\ \ll\textrm{N}\gg≪2(cosθ)N−W​=(2)(0.87)30−10​=≫11.5≪N≫Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The weight ofM1M_1M1​is supported by the force of reactionR31R_{31}R31​of theM3M_3M3​onM1M_1M1​. ThereforeW(cos⁡θ)=R31W(\cos\theta)=R_{31}W(cosθ)=R31​whereθ\thetaθis the angle shown on the diagram below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c1073f-1058-406c-9d31-7ea31814fde3/images/8759817a-d2cf-403b-9d88-6f93199347be/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%209.48.31%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

The lengthLcan be found with the Pythagoras theoremL=102−52=8.7L=\sqrt{{10}^2-5^2}=8.7L=102−52​=8.7cmFindingcos⁡θ\cos\thetacosθcos⁡θ=8.6710=0.87\cos\theta=\dfrac{8.67}{10}=0.87cosθ=108.67​=0.87R31=Wcos⁡θR_{31}=\dfrac{W}{\cos\theta}R31​=cosθW​R31=100.87=11.5R_{31}=\dfrac{10}{0.87}=11.5R31​=0.8710​=11.5NAlternative solution‾\underline{\textrm{Alternative solution}}Alternative solution​:According to Newton's Third Law, the force of reactionR31R_{31}R31​of theM3M_3M3​onM1M_1M1​equals the force of the reactionR13R_{13}R13​of theM1M_1M1​onM3M_3M3​. The vertical component of theR13R_{13}R13​can be found with the help of geometry

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c1073f-1058-406c-9d31-7ea31814fde3/images/9338dc86-1aa1-47bc-9412-01f90ad79a7c/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%209.48.35%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

The lengthLcan be found with the Pythagorean theoremL=102−52=8.7L=\sqrt{{10}^2-5^2}=8.7L=102−52​=8.7cmFindingcos⁡θ\cos\thetacosθcos⁡θ=8.6710=0.87\cos\theta=\dfrac{8.67}{10}=0.87cosθ=108.67​=0.87According to Newton's Third Law, the force of reactionR31R_{31}R31​of theM3M_3M3​onM1M_1M1​equals the force of the reactionR13R_{13}R13​of theM1M_1M1​onM3M_3M3​. list.title: Question 81
list.content: A ball is falling vertically in a liquid. The overall density of the ball and the density of the liquid are the same. Which of the following is correct for the change in speed of the ball and and the direction of the acceleration?\hspace{1.5em}The motion of the ball\hspace{1.5em}Acceleration\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}Speeding upUpwards\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}Slowing downUpwards\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}Speeding upDownwards\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}Slowing down\hspace{1.5em}Downwards\hspace{1.5em}
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Three forces are acting on the ball the weight of the ball, buoyancy, and drag. While buoyancy and drag are upwards, weight is downwards.The buoyancy :FB=ρliquidVgF_B = {\rho}_{liquid}VgFB​=ρliquid​VgWeight:W=mg=ρballVgW=mg={\rho}_{ball}VgW=mg=ρball​VgSince the density of the ball and the liquid are the same, weight and buoyancy cancel each other and the net force acting on the ball is the drag force. Due to having upward net force while moving downwards, the ball must be slowing down. Moreover, if the initial speed was zero at the time of contact with the water, the ball would experience zero net force. The drag force provides a net upwards force, so the acceleration of the ball is upwards.
